awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Large Scale Cultivation of Phytoplankton via Novel Photo-Bioreactor Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to provide a sustainable, low-cost, and replicable method for large-scale production of micro-algal biomass. Microalgae production is a form of aquaculture capable of producing valuable products including:  Nutraceuticals, specialty chemicals, pharmaceuticals, feed for finfish, shellfish, and livestock, as well as food for human consumption.  Moreover, microalgae can be used as a feedstock for biofuels while simultaneously removing CO2 from the environment.   However, for the nascent algae cultivation industry to achieve its full commercial potential, the technology must be improved.  While typical algal cultivation relies on high-density cell growth, this project will focus on the science of low-density algal cultivation to achieve high productivity, while minimizing process requirements for supplemental energy and concentrated CO2.  In addition, the development of a closed-system photo-bioreactor with emphasis on low cost and modular design will allow the process to be easily replicated on a variety of lands with otherwise marginal value. As such, the system can become the basis for a robust aquaculture and biofuels industry, leading to greater economic development in marginal communities and a source of sustainable products for the growing world population. 

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to further optimize the design of the large-scale algal production system developed during the Phase I project to address key challenges in algae cultivation including frequent contamination, low productivity, and increased operating costs due to inefficient use of water and energy. Research activities will focus on four main objectives: 1) Finalize key design specifications for reactor geometry, materials of construction, and system components in order to maximize productivity and minimize capital costs; 2) optimize harvest apparatus design and biomass concentration procedure to further reduce water consumption; 3) develop a new media formulation to allow for stable pH control without the need for concentrated CO2; and 4) refine manufacturing of the reactor bladder to ensure sterility, durability, and product consistency.  In addition to the basic algae cultivation techniques employed in Phase I, Phase II will make greater use of engineering /computational analyses to arrive at optimal designs.  The target outcome of the project is a 120,000-L closed photo-bioreactor capable of sustaining H. pluvialis algae production rates of greater than 9 g/m2/d for a minimum of 4 months without detrimental contamination.  In addition, the system will provide significant reductions in consumption of energy, water, and concentrated CO2.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Triangular Prism Algae Reactor (TriPARTM) is a closed photobioreactor system for cultivating suspended algae.  The reactor frame is built in the shape of a large triangular prism (6 ft. wide x 6.7ft. tall x 104ft. long) and is fabricated from aluminum tubing and vinyl-coated steel mesh.  Inside the metal support structure, the culture is contained by a 55,000-L plastic bag with aseptic ports for fluid transfers and process instrumentation.  A submersible, robotic, harvest apparatus operates inside the plastic bag and allows for removal of concentrated biomass while maintaining culture sterility.  Process plumbing, control valves, pumps, air blowers, and analytical instrumentation are all included in the system.   The modular nature of the TriPAR facilitates easy, linear expansion, while its proprietary design confers manufacturability at scale and simple, on-site assembly.

Oversite of the cultivation process, via the Harvest Apparatus Interface and Control Unit (HAICUTM) system, enables smooth process operation, including media charging, adjustment of air flow rate, pH control and collection of concentrated algae biomass.    The incorporation of Bluetooth wireless technology with an intuitive user interface supports remote monitoring and control of reactor functions via mobile device.  Furthermore, the  HAICUTM control system is designed to coordinate the operation of multiple units simultaneously to maximize plant efficiency.   By combining all these technological features into an integrated system, Pure Biomass aims to provide a comprehensive and efficient algae production platform that is commercially available to all sizes of customers.

The TriPARTM system offers several benefits to algae cultivation. 1.) The expansive reactor volume provides a large fluid reservoir to resist fluctuations in temperature and CO2 availability, thereby reducing energy requirements for active temperature control and high-intensity mass-transfer. 2.) The triangular geometry of the vessel provides enhanced light adsorption capabilities compared to flat ponds, vertical panels, and tubular reactors.  By placing gas sparge lines in the lower corners of the triangular prism, air bubbles are forced to rise along the inner walls, scouring the surface of biofilm and allowing better light uptake.  Furthermore, the reactor's triangular geometry is very stable against wind and seismic forces.  3.) The greater depth of the reactor creates dark zones where algae cells can periodically escape the intense illumination at the surface of the vessel thereby reducing culture stress.  4.) The use of a reusable / recyclable plastic bag for process containment allows users a quick turnaround in the event of a major culture contamination.   And 5.) the internal harvest apparatus, which is completely novel to algae cultivation, takes advantage of natural biomass settling and allows daily collection of algal biomass without the need to pump large amounts of fluid or sacrifice culture sterility.  This allows the operator to maintain a low cell density in the system while minimizing water and energy consumption.

Over the course of the project, the TriPAR has been used to cultivate numerous algae species with demonstrated commercial impact.  These include: Haematococcus pluvialis (human nutraceuticals and natural colorant for salmon and shrimp), Spirulina platensis (high fat and high protein food for humans and animals, food colorant, nutraceuticals), Nannochloropsis salina (high EPA content omega-3 fatty acids, feed for fish and shellfish, biofuels), Scenedesmus sp. (nitrogen and phosphorus recovery from wastewater, soil amendment, biofuels). 

Another outcome is the refinement of manufacturing techniques for constructing, complex, industrial-scale plastic enclosures, which can be useful in agriculture, chemical production, and other microbial cultivations.  Beyond the collection of settled algae, the TriPAR's submersible harvest robot is envisioned as a mobile platform for carrying multiple instruments and tools useful in a variety of aquaculture and water treatment processes.

 Most recently, the TriPARTM system was used as the basis for a second NSF SBIR project (# 2113705), which focused on evaluating the TriPARTM for recovery of nitrogen and phosphorus pollution from wastewater under continuous flow conditions.  If the TriPARTM can be developed into a commercially available wastewater treatment process, municipalities, farms, and industries can use the system to help achieve higher, water quality standards and cleanup their surrounding environment. 

Algae biomass produced from the TriPARTM can become a source of sustainable bioproducts with a range of applications including soil amendments, animal feeds, omega-3 fatty acids, specialty chemicals, human food and biofuels. Lastly, because the TriPARTM is designed for enhanced energy efficiency, water conservation, and customer affordability, it can be used to extract value from marginal lands and stimulate new economic growth.  Overall, the goal of Pure Biomass is to significantly lower barriers to algae cultivation, like access to innovative technologies and process knowledge and by reducing capital and operating costs associated with algae cultivation.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Georgiy V Vozhdayev

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Triangular Prism Algae Reactor (TriPARTM) is a closed photobioreactor system for cultivating suspended algae. The reactor frame is built in the shape of a large triangular prism (6 ft. wide x 6.7ft. tall x 104ft. long) and is fabricated from aluminum tubing and vinyl-coated steel mesh. Inside the metal support structure, the culture is contained by a 55,000-L plastic bag with aseptic ports for fluid transfers and process instrumentation. A submersible, robotic, harvest apparatus operates inside the plastic bag and allows for removal of concentrated biomass while maintaining culture sterility. Process plumbing, control valves, pumps, air blowers, and analytical instrumentation are all included in the system. The modular nature of the TriPAR facilitates easy, linear expansion, while its proprietary design confers manufacturability at scale and simple, on-site assembly.


Oversite of the cultivation process, via the Harvest Apparatus Interface and Control Unit (HAICUTM) system, enables smooth process operation, including media charging, adjustment of air flow rate, pH control and collection of concentrated algae biomass. The incorporation of Bluetooth wireless technology with an intuitive user interface supports remote monitoring and control of reactor functions via mobile device. Furthermore, the HAICUTM control system is designed to coordinate the operation of multiple units simultaneously to maximize plant efficiency. By combining all these technological features into an integrated system, Pure Biomass aims to provide a comprehensive and efficient algae production platform that is commercially available to all sizes of customers.


The TriPARTM system offers several benefits to algae cultivation. 1.) The expansive reactor volume provides a large fluid reservoir to resist fluctuations in temperature and CO2 availability, thereby reducing energy requirements for active temperature control and high-intensity mass-transfer. 2.) The triangular geometry of the vessel provides enhanced light adsorption capabilities compared to flat ponds, vertical panels, and tubular reactors. By placing gas sparge lines in the lower corners of the triangular prism, air bubbles are forced to rise along the inner walls, scouring the surface of biofilm and allowing better light uptake. Furthermore, the reactor's triangular geometry is very stable against wind and seismic forces. 3.) The greater depth of the reactor creates dark zones where algae cells can periodically escape the intense illumination at the surface of the vessel thereby reducing culture stress. 4.) The use of a reusable / recyclable plastic bag for process containment allows users a quick turnaround in the event of a major culture contamination. And 5.) the internal harvest apparatus, which is completely novel to algae cultivation, takes advantage of natural biomass settling and allows daily collection of algal biomass without the need to pump large amounts of fluid or sacrifice culture sterility. This allows the operator to maintain a low cell density in the system while minimizing water and energy consumption.


Over the course of the project, the TriPAR has been used to cultivate numerous algae species with demonstrated commercial impact. Beyond the collection of settled algae, the TriPAR's submersible harvest robot is envisioned as a mobile platform for carrying multiple instruments and tools useful in a variety of aquaculture and water treatment processes.


Most recently, the TriPARTM system was used as the basis for a second NSF SBIR project (# 2113705), which focused on evaluating the TriPARTM for recovery of nitrogen and phosphorus pollution from wastewater under continuous flow conditions. If the TriPARTM can be developed into a commercially available wastewater treatment process, municipalities, farms, and industries can use the system to help achieve higher, water quality standards and cleanup their surrounding environment.


Algae biomass produced from the TriPARTM can become a source of sustainable bioproducts with a range of applications including soil amendments, animal feeds, omega-3 fatty acids, specialty chemicals, human food and biofuels. Lastly, because the TriPARTM is designed for enhanced energy efficiency, water conservation, and customer affordability, it can be used to extract value from marginal lands and stimulate new economic growth. Overall, the goal of Pure Biomass is to significantly lower barriers to algae cultivation, like access to innovative technologies and process knowledge and by reducing capital and operating costs associated with algae cultivation.
